metadata.title: Global stability of the endemic equilibrium of a discrete SIR epidemic model

body_text.text: Mathematical models have played a significant role in describing the dynamical evolution of infectious diseases. SIR model is one of the classical epidemic models with compartment structure, suitable for the transmission of infectious diseases that confer long-lasting immunity such as chicken pox and SARS. The host population is divided into three epidemiological groups: the susceptibles, the infectives, and the removed/recovered. The transmission dynamics of an infectious disease is described by modeling the population movements among those epidemiological compartments.
body_text.section: 1 Introduction

body_text.text: There is an increasing interest in the study and application of discrete epidemic models. Allen et al. have studied some discrete-time SI, SIR, and SIS epidemic models, compared the dynamics of deterministic and stochastic discrete-time epidemic models, and also applied the discrete epidemic model to the spread of rabies [1–3]. Allen and Driessche have given the basic reproductive number for some discrete-time epidemic models [4]. Castillo-Chavez and Yakubu have investigated a discrete SIS model with complex dynamics [5]. Zhou et al. have formulated and discussed the dynamical behavior of age-structured SIS models [6, 7]. A stage-structured model, a discrete epidemic model with seasonal variation in environment, a discrete tuberculosis transmission model, and many other discrete epidemic models have been constructed, studied, and applied [8–10]. One reason for the upsurge of discrete epidemic models is that discrete models have advantages in describing an infectious disease since epidemic data are usually collected in discrete time units, which would make it more convenient to use discrete-time models [11].
body_text.section: 1 Introduction

body_text.text: The studies on discrete epidemic models are relatively few compared with those on continuous epidemic models. Most research works on discrete epidemic models concern the definition of the basic reproductive number, the global stability of the disease free equilibrium, the persistence of diseases, the existence and local stability of endemic equilibria, the existence of flip bifurcation and Hopf bifurcation. The results on the global stability of the endemic equilibrium are quite few for discrete epidemic models due to the following two factors: (1) There is not enough effective theory and methods for global stability of discrete dynamical systems; (2) The discrete model exhibits much more complicated dynamical behaviors than its corresponding continuous model.
body_text.section: 1 Introduction

body_text.text: We will study the global stability of the endemic equilibrium of a discrete SIR model and get sufficient conditions. The discrete SIR model, the biological requirement of the model, the basic reproductive number, and the invariant domain of the model are given in the next section. The global stability of disease free equilibrium and the persistence are discussed in Section 3. The sufficient conditions for the global stability of endemic equilibrium are obtained in Section 4. Numerical simulations and application are presented to demonstrate our theoretical results, to show the complex dynamics and application example of the model in Section 5. Conclusions and discussions are included in the last section.
body_text.section: 1 Introduction

body_text.text: There are different approaches to model infectious disease evolution in discrete time. The recurrent difference equations from the discretization of continuous differential equation models is one of the direct and frequently-used modeling approaches. This kind of model can be well understood in application under reasonable assumptions though there are some limitations on the range of parameters. We will adopt this approach to formulate model and assume that the infected people will obtain permanent immunity after they get recovered from infection.
body_text.section: 2 The discrete SIR model

body_text.text: Let N(t) denote the number of the host population at time t. According to the disease transmission mechanism, the host population is grouped into three epidemiological compartments. Let S(t), I(t), and R(t) be the number of individuals in the susceptible, infective, and removed/recovered compartments at time t, respectively. In addition to the death and recruitment, there are population movements among those three epidemiological compartments from time unit t to time t+1. We assume that the recruited individuals (by birth and immigration) are constant and enter the susceptible compartment. After one unit time, the susceptible individuals may stay in the susceptible compartment, or get infected and move to the infectious compartment, or die. The individuals in the infective compartment can keep being the infective, or get recover and transfer to the recovered compartment, or die. The individuals in the recovered compartment never leave the compartment unless they die. The discrete SIR model is 1{S(t+1)=S(t)+Λ−βS(t)I(t)N(t)−μS(t),I(t+1)=I(t)+βS(t)I(t)N(t)−(μ+δ+γ)I(t),R(t+1)=R(t)+γI(t)−μR(t),
body_text.section: 2 The discrete SIR model

body_text.text: where Λ is the constant recruitment rate of the population, β is the transmission rate, μ is the natural death rate, δ is the death rate caused by disease, and γ is the recovery rate. The biological background requires that all parameters be non-negative.
body_text.section: 2 The discrete SIR model

body_text.text: There is abundant amount of research into SIR models since they capture the basic evolution mechanism of the infectious diseases when the recovered individuals will acquire life-long immunity. A lot of results on the existence and global stability of the endemic equilibrium have been obtained for continuous SIR models with various transmission rate. However, the result on the global stability of the endemic equilibrium for discrete SIR model is rare, even for the model with mass action incidence. We will try to give sufficient conditions for the global stability of the endemic equilibrium. Those results on global stability of the endemic equilibrium can promote the study on this challengeable problem.
body_text.section: 2 The discrete SIR model

body_text.text: Adding all equations in (1), we see that the number of host population, N(t), satisfies 2N(t+1)=N(t)+Λ−μN(t)−δI(t)≤Λ+(1−μ)N(t).
body_text.section: 2 The discrete SIR model

body_text.text: The equation N˜(t+1)=Λ+(1−μ)N˜(t) has a unique equilibrium N˜∗=Λμ, which is globally asymptotically stable, namely, limt→∞N˜(t)=N˜∗. The comparison principle implies that N(t)≤N˜(t)≤N˜∗ when N(0)≤N˜(0)≤N˜∗. In the analysis of model (1), we assume that 30≤S(0),0≤I(0),0≤R(0)andS(0)+I(0)+R(0)≤N˜∗.
body_text.section: 2 The discrete SIR model

body_text.text: The epidemiological interpretation requires the solution of model (1) with initial values satisfying (3) to be non-negative. This requirement can be met if the following two inequalities hold: 4β+μ<1,μ+δ+γ<1.
body_text.section: 2 The discrete SIR model

body_text.text: Those two conditions in (4) are natural requirements for model (1). The first inequality, β+μ<1, says that the percentage of the susceptible individuals who die or get infected is less than one within a unit time. The second inequality, μ+δ+γ<1, states that the percentage of the infected people who die or get recovered is less than one within a unit time. It is easy to verify that those two inequalities ensure S(t)≥0, I(t)≥0, and R(t)≥0 for all t≥0 if the initial values satisfy (3).
body_text.section: 2 The discrete SIR model

body_text.text: In the rest of the paper, we assume that the initial conditions and the parameters satisfy (3) and (4), respectively. It is easy to verify that the domain Ω1={(S,I,R)∈R+3|S+I+R≤Λμ}
body_text.section: 2 The discrete SIR model

body_text.text: is a compact, positively invariant set for model (1). Ω1 is also a global compact attractor of system (1) since it attracts all positive orbits with an initial value (S0,I0,R0)∈R+3.
body_text.section: 2 The discrete SIR model

body_text.text: The basic reproductive number, R0, is fundamental and widely used in the study of epidemiological models. R0 is the average number of secondary infections produced by one infected individual during the entire course of infection in a completely susceptible population. R0 often serves as a threshold parameter that predicts whether an infection dies out or keeps persistence in a population. Following the idea and framework given in [4, 12, 13], we obtain the formula of the basic reproduction number of model (1), R0=βμ+δ+γ. The magnitude of R0 plays a crucial role in determining the dynamical behavior of model (1).
body_text.section: 2 The discrete SIR model

body_text.text: This section focuses on the disease extinction or persistence, which is determined by the stability of the disease free equilibrium and the existence of endemic equilibrium of model (1). It is obvious that E0(Λμ,0,0) is an equilibrium of model (1). E0 is called the disease free equilibrium since I and R components are zero. The stability of the disease free equilibrium E0 is given in the following theorem.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text:
Theorem 1
The disease free equilibrium
E0
of model (1) is globally asymptotically stable if
R0<1, and
E0
is unstable if
R0>1.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: Proof The linearized matrix of (1) at the disease free equilibrium E0 is A=(1−μ−β001+β−μ−δ−γ00γ1−μ).
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: Obviously, the eigenvalues of matrix A are λ1=λ2=1−μ and λ3=1+β−μ−δ−γ, respectively. The conditions β+μ<1, μ+δ+γ<1, and R0<1 imply that |λi|<1, i=1,2,3. Therefore, the disease free equilibrium E0 is asymptotically stable. When R0>1, we have λ3=1+β−μ−δ−γ>1, then the disease free equilibrium E0 is unstable.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: From the second equation of model (1) and the fact S(t)≤N(t), we have 5I(t+1)≤I(t)+βI(t)−(μ+δ+γ)I(t)=(1−(μ+δ+γ)(1−R0))I(t).
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: The conditions μ+δ+γ<1 and R0<1 imply that 0<1−(μ+δ+γ)(1−R0)<1. The recurrent use of inequality (5) yields 6I(t)=(1−(μ+δ+γ)(1−R0))tI(0).
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: The inequality (6) implies that limt→∞I(t)=0.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: From the fact limt→∞I(t)=0, we know that for any ε>0, there exists a large positive integer T1 such that I(t)<ε when t≥T1. Consequently, 7R(t+1)=R(t)+γI(t)−μR(t)≤R(t)+γε−μR(t)for t≥T1.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: The equation R˜(t+1)=R˜(t)+γε−μR˜(t) has a unique equilibrium R˜∗=γεμ, which is globally asymptotically stable. The comparison principle implies that there exists an integer T2>T1 such that R(t)≤R˜(t)<2γεμ if t>T2. The arbitrary ε implies that limt→∞R(t)=0.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: From (2) we have 8N(t)+Λ−δε−μN(t)≤N(t+1)≤Λ+(1−μ)N(t)if t>T1.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: From the left inequality of (8) and the comparison principle, we know that for any given ε1>0, there exists an integer T3>T1 such that N(t)≥Λ−δεμ−ε1 for all t>T3. From the right inequality of (8) and the comparison principle, we know that for any given ε2>0, there exists an integer T4>T1 such that N(t)≤Λμ+ε2 for all t>T4. Let T5=T3+T4, then the inequalities Λ−δεμ−ε1≤N(t)≤Λμ+ε2for all t>T5,
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: and the arbitrary ε, ε1, and ε2 imply that limt→∞N(t)=Λμ, i.e., limt→∞S(t)=limt→∞(N(t)−I(t)−R(t))=Λμ. Those limits limt→∞S(t)=Λμ,limt→∞I(t)=0,limt→∞R(t)=0
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: imply that the disease free equilibrium of (1) is globally asymptotically stable when R0<1. □
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: R0>1 means that the average number of a new infection by an infected individual is more than one. The epidemiological interpretation indicates that the disease may keep persistent in the population. The following theorem confirms the persistence of the disease in the case R0>1.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text:
Theorem 2
If
R0>1, then the disease will keep persistence in the population, i.e., there exists a positive
ε
such that the solution of model (1) with the initial value
I(0)>0
satisfies
lim inft→∞I(t)>ε.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: Proof We define the sets X=Ω1={(S,I,R)∈R+3∣S+I+R≤Λμ}, X0={(S,I,R)∈X∣I>0,R>0}, and ∂X0=X∖X0. Let Φ:X→X, Φt(x0)=ϕ(t,x0), be the solution map of model (1) with ϕ(0,x0)=x0 and x0=(S(0),I(0),R(0)). Let M={Φ0}=(Λμ,0,0) and M∂={(S,I,R)∈∂X0∣Φt(S,I,R)∈∂X0,∀t≥0}.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: It is clear that {(S,0,0)∈∂X0∣S≥0}⊂M∂ and M∂={(S,I,R)∈∂X0∣I=0}. Furthermore, there is exactly one fixed point Φ0 of Φ in M∂. The equation S1(t+1)=Λ+(1−μ)S1(t)
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: has a positive equilibrium S∗=Λμ, which is globally attractive. By using Lemma 5.9 in [14], we know that no subset of ℳ forms a cycle in ∂X0. The fact Φt((S(0),0,R(0)))=(S(t),0,R(t)) implies that Φt(M∂)⊂M∂. If x0=(S(0),0,R(0))∈M∂, then we have limt→∞S(t)=Λμ, limt→∞R(t)=limt→∞(1−μ)tR(0)=0, and Ω(M∂)=Φ0.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: Since 0≤I(t)≤N(t) and N(t+1)=Λ+N(t)−μN(t)−δI(t), we have N(t+1)≥N(t)+Λ−(μ+δ)N(t) and N(t+1)≤N(t)+Λ−μN(t). The difference equation N1(t+1)=Λ+(1−μ−δ)N1(t) has a unique equilibrium N1∗=Λμ+δ, and N(t+1)=N(t)+Λ−μN(t) has a unique equilibrium N2∗=Λμ, which is globally asymptotically stable. Therefore, for any given ε>0, there exists a T1>0 such that Λ(μ+δ)−ε≤N(t)≤Λμ+ε for all t≥T1.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: If R0>1, then we can prove that there exists a small positive number σ such that 9lim supt→∞d(Φt(S0,I0,R0),Φ0)≥σfor (S0,I0,R0)∈X0.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: If the conclusion in (9) does not hold, then for any positive number σ, there exist a point (Sσ0,Iσ0,Rσ0)∈X0 and a large T2>T1 such that 10d(Φt(Sσ0,Iσ0,Rσ0),Φ0)<σfor t>T2.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: The inequality in (10) implies that 11I(t)≤σandS(t)>Λμ−σif t>T2.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: When t>T2, the equations in (1) imply that 12N(t+1)≤N(t)+Λ−μN(t),I(t+1)>I(t)+β(Λμ−σ)I(t)N(t)−(μ+δ+γ)I(t).
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: From the first inequality in (12), we know that there exists a number T3>T2 such that N(t)≤Λμ holds for all t>T3. When t>T3, we substitute the inequality N(t)≤Λμ into the second inequality of (12) to obtain 13I(t+1)>I(t)+β(Λ−μσ)I(t)Λ−(μ+δ+γ)I(t)=I(t)(1+(R0(1−μσ/Λ)−1)(μ+δ+γ)).
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: If we choose σ small enough, then the condition R0>1 implies that 14R0(1−μσ/Λ)−1>0and1+(R0(1−μσ/Λ)−1)(μ+γ)>1.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: From the inequalities in (13) and (14), we have that limt→∞I(t)=∞. The limit limt→∞I(t)=∞ contradicts the inequality I(t)<σ in (11). The contradiction comes from the assumption given in (10). Therefore, the conclusion in (9) holds true. Subsequently, Ws(Φ0)∩X0=∅ and Φ0 is isolated in X. From Theorem 1.3.1 and Remark 1.3.1 in [15], it follows that Φ is uniformly persistent with respect to (X0,∂X0). Furthermore, Theorem 1.3.4 in [15] implies that the solutions of model (1) are uniformly persistent with respect to (X0,∂X0) when R0>1. That is, there exists an ε>0 such that lim inft→∞I(t)>ε>0. □
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: The conditions in Theorem 1 and Theorem 2 are very simple though the proof is long and complicated. It is very easy to determine whether the disease goes to extinction or keeps persistence in the population by the magnitude of the basic reproductive number, R0. The underlining mechanism of the nice threshold result given in Theorem 1 is that the number of the infected population will gradually become lower and lower if the new infection created by an individual during his/her infection period is less than one. The epidemiological interpretation of Theorem 2 says that there is at least a certain number of infected population if the new infection created by an individual during his/her infection period is more than one. The necessary condition is to eliminate an infectious disease, to reduce R0, and to have R0<1. The basis reproductive number, R0, is a very useful quantity in mathematical analysis and epidemiological application.
body_text.section: 3 Extinction and persistence for the disease

body_text.text: This section deals with the existence and stability of the endemic equilibrium of model (1). Let E∗(S∗,I∗,R∗) be the endemic equilibrium of model (1). Then S∗, I∗, and R∗ satisfy the following equations: Λ−βS∗I∗N∗−μS∗=0,βS∗N∗−(μ+δ+γ)=0,γI∗−μR∗=0,
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: where N∗=S∗+I∗+R∗. By straightforward and careful calculations, we know that model (1) has a unique endemic equilibrium when R0>1 with S∗=Λ(μ+γ)μ((μ+δ+γ)(R0−1)+(μ+γ)),I∗=Λ(R0−1)(μ+δ+γ)(R0−1)+(μ+γ),R∗=γI∗μ.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: The local stability of the endemic equilibrium E∗ is given in the following theorem.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text:
Theorem 3
If
R0>1, then the endemic equilibrium
E∗=(S∗,I∗,R∗)
of model (1) is locally asymptotically stable.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: Proof In order to discuss the stability of the endemic equilibrium of model (1), we consider the following equivalent system: 15{N(t+1)=N(t)+Λ−μN(t)−δI(t),I(t+1)=I(t)+(μ+δ+γ)(R0−1)I(t)−βI(t)2N(t)−βI(t)R(t)N(t),R(t+1)=R(t)+γI(t)−μR(t).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: When R0>1, the positive equilibrium of system (15) is (N∗,I∗,R∗), where N∗=Λ(μ+γ)R0μ((μ+δ+γ)(R0−1)+(μ+γ)).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: The linearization matrix of (15) at the positive equilibrium (N∗,I∗,R∗) is A1=(1−μ−δ0βI∗(I∗+R∗)N∗21−βI∗N∗−βI∗N∗0γ1−μ).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: The characteristic equation of matrix A1 is ϕ(λ)=(1−μ−λ)((1−μ−λ)(1−βI∗N∗−λ)+γβI∗N∗+δβI∗(I∗+R∗)N∗2).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: We see that the equation ϕ(λ)=0 has an eigenvalue 0<λ1=1−μ<1. Therefore, in order to determine the stability of the positive equilibrium of model (15), we discuss the roots of the following equation: ϕ1(λ)=(1−μ−λ)(1−βI∗N∗−λ)+γβI∗N∗+δβI∗(I∗+R∗)N∗2=λ2−(2−μ−βI∗N∗)λ+(1−μ)(1−βI∗N∗)+γβI∗N∗+δβI∗(I∗+R∗)N∗2.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: When R0>1, the calculation yields ϕ1(1)=1−(2−μ−βI∗N∗)+(1−μ)(1−βI∗N∗)+γβI∗N∗+δβI∗(I∗+R∗)N∗2=μβI∗N∗+γβI∗N∗+δβI∗(I∗+R∗)N∗2>0,ϕ1(−1)=1+(2−μ−βI∗N∗)+(1−μ)(1−βI∗N∗)+γβI∗N∗+δβI∗(I∗+R∗)N∗2=2(1−μ−βI∗N∗)+2+μβI∗N∗+γβI∗N∗+δβI∗(I∗+R∗)N∗2>2(1−μ−β)+2+μβI∗N∗+γβI∗N∗+δβI∗(I∗+R∗)N∗2>0.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: Furthermore, the constant term satisfies c=(1−μ)(1−βI∗N∗)+γβI∗N∗+δβI∗(I∗+R∗)N∗2=1−μ−βI∗N∗+γβI∗N∗+δβI∗N∗R0−1R0<1−μ−(1−μ−δ−γ)βI∗N∗<1.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: The Jury criterion [16] implies that the two roots, λ2 and λ3, of the equation ϕ1(λ)=0 satisfy |λ2|<1 and |λ3|<1. The linearization theory implies that the positive equilibrium (N∗,I∗,R∗) of system (15) is locally asymptotically stable if R0>1, i.e., the endemic equilibrium E∗ of system (1) is locally asymptotically stable. □
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: The global stability of the endemic equilibrium E∗ of model (1) is quite difficult. Sufficient conditions are presented in two theorems for the special case δ=0 and for the general case.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text:
Theorem 4
Assume that
δ=0. The endemic equilibrium
E∗(S∗,I∗,R∗)
of model (1) is globally asymptotically stable if
R0>μ+γμ
and
γ<μ.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: Proof When δ=0, the host population N(t)=S(t)+I(t)+R(t) satisfies 16N(t+1)=Λ+(1−μ)N(t),N(0)=N0>0,
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: which has the solution N(t)=Λ(1−(1−μ)t)μ+(1−μ)tN0.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: From the solution of the host population, we have that limt→∞N(t)=N∗=Λμ, and the limit of N(t) is independent of the initial value N0.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: The global stability of the endemic equilibrium, E∗, of model (1) is equivalent to the global stability of the endemic equilibrium EN∗(N∗,S∗,I∗) of the following model: 17{N(t+1)=Λ+(1−μ)N(t),S(t+1)=S(t)+Λ−βS(t)I(t)N(t)−μS(t),I(t+1)=I(t)+βS(t)I(t)N(t)−(μ+γ)I(t).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: The first equation of model (17) is independent of other two state variables S(t) and I(t). The fact that limt→∞N(t)=N∗ leads to the following limit model: 18{S(t+1)=S(t)+Λ−βμS(t)I(t)Λ−μS(t),I(t+1)=I(t)+βμS(t)I(t)Λ−(μ+γ)I(t).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: The limiting model (18) possesses the same dynamical property as that of model (17). Both equations of model (18) are nonlinear, but with a similar term βμS(t)I(t)Λ. We introduce the new variable L(t)=S(t)+I(t) to have one linear equation, then we have 19L(t+1)=L(t)+Λ−γI(t)−μL(t),I(t+1)=I(t)+βμ(L(t)−I(t))I(t)Λ−(μ+γ)I(t).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: The global stability of the positive equilibrium of model (19) is equivalent to that of model (17). From the inequality 0≤I(t)≤L(t) and the first equation of (19), we have 20L(t+1)≤L(t)+Λ−μL(t),L(t+1)≥L(t)+Λ−(μ+γ)L(t).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: From those two inequalities in (20) and the comparison theorem [17], we know that for any small ε>0, there exists a positive integer T1l such that L1l≤L(t)≤L1m for t>T1l, where L1l=Λμ+γ−ε and L1m=Λμ+ε.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: When t≥T1l, we substitute L1l≤L(t)≤L1m into the second equation of (19) to obtain 21I(t+1)≤I(t)+βμ(L1m−I(t))I(t)Λ−(μ+γ)I(t),I(t+1)≥I(t)+βμ(L1l−I(t))I(t)Λ−(μ+γ)I(t).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: We consider the following two difference equations corresponding to the inequalities in (21): 22{I1m(t+1)=I1m(t)+βμ(L1m−I1m(t))I1m(t)Λ−(μ+γ)I1m(t),I1l(t+1)=I1l(t)+βμ(L1l−I1l(t))I1l(t)Λ−(μ+γ)I1l(t).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: We substitute I1m(t)=Λ+βμL1m−Λ(μ+γ)βμx1m(t) and I1l(t)=Λ+βμL1l−Λ(μ+γ)βμx1l(t) into the first and the second equations of (22) to have 23{x1m(t+1)=r1mx1m(t)(1−x1m(t)),with r1m=1−(μ+γ)+βμL1mΛ,x1l(t+1)=r1lx1l(t)(1−x1l(t)),with r1l=1−(μ+γ)+βμL1lΛ.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: The variables x1m(t) and x1l(t) satisfy the quadratic difference equation. The well-known result of the famous population model x(t+1)=rx(t)(1−x(t)) says that x0∗=0 is the unique and globally asymptotically stable equilibrium if 0<r<1, whereas x1∗=1−1r is the unique positive equilibrium if 1<r<3 and x1∗ is globally asymptotically stable. The result on the quadratic population model x(t+1)=rx(t)(1−x(t)) implies that the first equation in (22) has a positive equilibrium I1∗m=L1m−ΛμR0, which is globally asymptotically stable. A similar argument implies that the second equation in (22) has a positive equilibrium I1∗l=L1l−ΛμR0, which is globally asymptotically stable if R0>μ+γμ.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: The asymptotical stability and the comparison theory imply that there exists a T1i≥T1l such that I1l≤I(t)≤I1m for all t>T1i, where I1l=I1∗l−ε and I1m=I1∗m+ε. When t≥T1i, we substitute the inequality I1l≤I(t)≤I1m into the first equation of (19) and have 24L(t+1)≤L(t)+Λ−μL(t)−γI1l,L(t+1)≥L(t)+Λ−μL(t)−γI1m.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: From (24) and a similar argument, we can obtain that there exists a positive integer T2l such that L2l≤L(t)≤L2m for all t≥T2l, where L2l=Λ−γI1mμ−ε, L2m=Λ−γI1lμ+ε, and L1l<L2l<L2m<L1m.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: When t≥T2l, the inequality L2l≤L(t)≤L2m and the second equation of (19) imply that 25I(t+1)≤I(t)+βμ(L2m−I(t))I(t)Λ−(μ+γ)I(t),I(t+1)≥I(t)+βμ(L2l−I(t))I(t)Λ−(μ+γ)I(t).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: A similar argument implies that there exists a T2i≥T2l such that I2l≤I(t)≤I2m for all t>T2i, where I2l=L2l−ΛμR0−ε and I2m=L2m−ΛμR0+ε. After substituting L2m=Λ−γI1lμ+ε and L2l=Λ−γI1mμ−ε into the equations I2m=L2m−ΛμR0+ε and I2l=L2l−ΛμR0−ε, we have 26{I2m=−γI1lμ+Λ(R0−1)R0μ+2ε,I2l=−γI1mμ+Λ(R0−1)R0μ−2ε.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: Equations in (26) hold when t>T2i and I2l≤I(t)≤I2m. From the mathematical induction, we know that there exist sequences Tkl, Tki, Lkl, Lkm, Ikl, and Ikm such that Ikl<I(t)<Ikm for all t>Tki. Furthermore, Ikl and Ikm satisfy the following recurrence equations: 27{Ik+1m=−γIklμ+Λ(R0−1)R0μ+2ε,Ik+1l=−γIkmμ+Λ(R0−1)R0μ−2ε.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: (27) is a linear system of difference equations. System (27) has a positive equilibrium P∗i(I∗l(ε),I∗m(ε)), where 28I∗l(ε)=μΛ−Λγ+Λ(γ2−μ2)β−2εμ2−2εμγμ2−γ2,I∗m(ε)=Λ−γI∗l(ε)μ−Λ(μ+γ)βμ+2ε.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: Let λ1 and λ2 be two roots of the linearized matrix of system (27) at the equilibrium P∗i. It is easy to see that |λ1|=|λ2|=γμ<1 if γ<μ. The stability theory of difference equations implies that the equilibrium P∗i of (27) is globally asymptotically stable, i.e., limk→∞Ikl=I∗l(ε) and limk→∞Ikm=I∗m(ε). From the expressions of I∗l(ε) and I∗m(ε), we have that limε→0I∗l(ε)=limε→0I∗m(ε)=Λ(R0−1)β. From the inequality Ikl<I(t)<Ikm and those limits, we obtain that limt→∞I(t)=Λ(R0−1)β.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: Similarly, we can prove that the sequences {Lkl} and {Lkm} satisfy a linear system of difference equations. The sequences {Lkl} and {Lkm} tend to the same limit when k tends to infinity and ε tends to zero, i.e., limk→∞Lkl=limk→∞Lkm=Λ(βμ+γ(μ+γ))μ(μ+γ)βas ε→0.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: The inequality Lkl<L(t)<Lkm and the limit imply limt→∞L(t)=Λ(βμ+γ(μ+γ))μ(μ+γ)β. Finally, we have limt→∞S(t)=limt→∞(L(t)−I(t))=Λ(μ+γ)μβandlimt→∞R(t)=limt→∞(N(t)−L(t))=Λγ(R0−1)μβ.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: Therefore, the endemic equilibrium of system (18) is globally asymptotic stable when R0>μ+γμ and γ<μ. Equivalently, the endemic equilibrium of system (1) is globally asymptotic stable. □
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: The comparison principle is the main idea to prove Theorem 4. The limitation of the method and the construction of the comparison equations may lead to the imposed conditions R0>μ+γμ and γ≤μ. We do hope that the global stability of the endemic equilibrium can be proved under the condition R0>1. When δ>0, the global stability condition of endemic equilibrium is more complicated. We use the same idea to get the sufficient stability conditions.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text:
Theorem 5
If
μ>δ+γ, μ2>(μ+δ)(μ+δ+γ)22+μ+δ+γ
and
max{μ+δ+γμ,δμ−δ−γ}<R0<(1+2μ+δ+γ)μμ+δ,
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text:
then the endemic equilibrium
E∗(S∗,I∗,R∗)
of model (1) is globally asymptotically stable.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: Proof Let L(t)=S(t)+I(t) and N(t)=L(t)+R(t). We consider the equivalent model 29
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: The definitions of L(t) and N(t) show that 0≤I(t)≤L(t)≤N(t). The global stability of endemic equilibrium (29) is equivalent to that of model (1). From the first equation of system (29), we have 30N(t+1)≤N(t)+Λ−μN(t),N(t+1)≥N(t)+Λ−(μ+δ)N(t).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: From (30) and the comparison theorem, we know that for any small ε>0, there exists a positive integer T1n such that N1l≤N(t)≤N1m for all t>T1n, where N1l=Λμ+δ−ε and N1m=Λμ+ε. From the second equation of system (29), we have 31L(t+1)≤L(t)+Λ−μL(t),L(t+1)≥L(t)+Λ−(μ+δ+γ)L(t).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: From (31) and the comparison theorem [17], we know that there exists a positive integer T1l such that L1l≤L(t)≤L1m for all t>T1l, where L1l=Λμ+γ+δ−ε and L1m=Λμ+ε.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: When t>T1c=max{T1n,T1l}, the inequalities N1l≤N(t)≤N1m, L1l≤L(t)≤L1m, and the third equation of (29) can yield 32I(t+1)≤I(t)+βL1m−I(t)N1lI(t)−(μ+δ+γ)I(t),I(t+1)≥I(t)+βL1l−I(t)N1mI(t)−(μ+δ+γ)I(t).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: The comparison equations corresponding to those inequalities in (32), 33I1m(t+1)=I1m(t)+βL1m−I1m(t)N1lI1m(t)−(μ+δ+γ)I1m(t),I1l(t+1)=I1l(t)+βL1l−I1l(t)N1mI1l(t)−(μ+δ+γ)I1l(t)
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: are the quadratic difference equations of the form x(t+1)=rx(t)(1−x(t)). When μ2>(μ+δ)(μ+δ+γ)22+μ+δ+γ and μ+δ+γμ<R0<(1+2μ+δ+γ)μμ+δ, the well-know result on the population model x(t+1)=rx(t)(1−x(t)) and the comparison theorem imply that there exists an integer T1i>T1c such that I1l≤I(t)≤I1m for all t>T1i, where I1l=L1l−N1mR0−ε and I1m=L1m−N1lR0+ε.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: When t≥T1i, we use the inequality I1l≤I(t)≤I1m in the first two equations of system (29) to get 34N(t+1)≤N(t)+Λ−μN(t)−δI1l,N(t+1)≥N(t)+Λ−μN(t)−δI1m,L(t+1)≤L(t)+Λ−μL(t)−(δ+γ)I1l,L(t+1)≥L(t)+Λ−μL(t)−(δ+γ)I1m.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: A similar argument implies that there exists a positive integer T2c such that N2l≤N(t)≤N2m and L2l≤L(t)≤L2m hold for t>T2c, where N2l=Λ−δI1mμ−ε, N2m=Λ−δI1lμ+ε, L2l=Λ−(γ+δ)I1mμ−ε, L2m=Λ−(γ+δ)I1lμ+ε, N1l<N2l<N2m<N1m, and L1l<L2l<L2m<L1m. When t>T2c, we use those estimates of N(t) and L(t) in the third equation of (29) and obtain the following inequalities: 35I(t+1)≤I(t)+βL2m−I(t)N2lI(t)−(μ+δ+γ)I(t),I(t+1)≥I(t)+βL2l−I(t)N2mI(t)−(μ+δ+γ)I(t).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: When μ2>(μ+δ)(μ+δ+γ)22+μ+δ+γ and μ+δ+γμ<R0<(1+2μ+δ+γ)μμ+δ, a similar procedure as aforementioned can imply that there exists an integer T2i>T2c such that I2l≤I(t)≤I2m for all t>T2i, where I2l=L2l−N2mR0−ε and I2m=L2m−N2lR0+ε.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: By using the mathematical induction, we obtain the sequences Tki, Nkl, Nkm, Lkl, Lkm, Ikl, and Ikm such that Nkl≤N(t)≤Nkm,Lkl≤L(t)≤Lkm,Ikl≤I(t)≤Ikm,t>Tik.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: Furthermore, Ikl and Ikm satisfy the following recurrence equations: 36Ik+1m=−δ+γμIkl+δR0μIkm+Λ(R0−1)R0μ+εR0+2ε,Ik+1l=−δ+γμIkm+δR0μIkl+Λ(R0−1)R0μ−εR0−2ε.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: (36) is a linear system of difference equations. Let z(k)=(Ikm,Ikl)τ, b=(Λ(R0−1)R0μ+εR0+2ε,Λ(R0−1)R0μ+εR0+2ε)τ, and B=(δR0μ−δ+γμ−δ+γμδR0μ),
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: then system (36) becomes 37z(k+1)=Bz(k)+b=Bk−1b+⋯+Bb+b+Bkz(1).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: If the conditions of Theorem 5 hold, then we know that the two eigenvalues of matrix B satisfy |λj|<1 (j=1,2), and the matrix series ∑k=0∞Bk converges to (I−B)−1. Under the conditions of Theorem 5, we can have limk→∞z(k)=(I−B)−1b, i.e., z∗=(I∗m,I∗l)=((I−B)−1b)τ is the globally stable equilibrium of (37). Further calculation shows that limε→0(I∗m,I∗l)=(Λ(R0−1)(μ+δ+γ)(R0−1)+(μ+γ),Λ(R0−1)(μ+δ+γ)(R0−1)+(μ+γ)).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: After taking ε→0, we have limk→∞Ikl=limk→∞Ikm=Λ(R0−1)(μ+δ+γ)(R0−1)+(μ+γ)andlimt→∞I(t)=Λ(R0−1)(μ+δ+γ)(R0−1)+(μ+γ)=Λ(R0−1)β−δ.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: A similar argument implies that limk→∞Nkl=limk→∞Nkm=Λ(μ+γ)R0μ((μ+δ+γ)(R0−1)+(μ+γ)),limt→∞N(t)=Λ(μ+γ)R0μ((μ+δ+γ)(R0−1)+(μ+γ)),limk→∞Lkl=limk→∞Lkm=Λ(μ+γ)+Λ(R0−1)μμ((μ+δ+γ)(R0−1)+(μ+γ)),limt→∞L(t)=Λ(μ+γ)+Λ(R0−1)μμ((μ+δ+γ)(R0−1)+(μ+γ)).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: Those limits lead to limt→∞S(t)=limt→∞(L(t)−I(t))=Λ(μ+γ)μ((μ+δ+γ)(R0−1)+(μ+γ))=Λ(γ+μ)(R0−1)β−δ,limt→∞R(t)=limt→∞(N(t)−L(t))=Λγ(R0−1)μ((μ+δ+γ)(R0−1)+(μ+γ))=Λγ(R0−1)μ(β−δ).
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: Therefore, the endemic equilibrium of system (1) is globally asymptotic stable when the conditions of Theorem 5 hold. □
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: There are some parameter values which can satisfy the conditions of Theorem 5. For example, if δ=γ=0, those conditions become μ>0, 1+μ>0, 1<R0<1+2μ. Then, for μ>0, we know that the conditions of Theorem 5 will hold if δ and γ are small enough.
body_text.section: 4 The stability of the endemic equilibrium

body_text.text: The simulations in this subsection demonstrate our theoretical results or the complex dynamics of the model. The parameter values for those simulations are selected mathematically to let the model exhibit required dynamics.
body_text.section: 5.1 Simulations of model (1) ::: 5 Numerical simulations

body_text.text: When δ=0, we choose μ=0.01, γ=0.006, Λ=20, and β=0.03, then γ<μ, μ+γμ=1.6, and R0=1.875>1.6. Theorem 4 implies that the endemic equilibrium E∗(S∗,I∗,R∗) of (1) is globally asymptotically stable. The number of the infectious individuals for two solutions with different initial values are shown in Figure 1(a). From Figure 1(a) we see that the number of infected people approaches its equilibrium value as t tends to infinity. For the same values of δ, μ, γ, and Λ, the straightforward calculation yields R0∈(1,1.6) if β∈(0.016,0.0256), which does not satisfy the condition R0>μ+γμ of Theorem 4. On the other hand, the simulation shows that the endemic equilibrium of model (1) may be globally asymptotically stable even if the condition R0>μ+γμ of Theorem 4 does not hold. The solution curves of the infected people for β=0.02 and two different initial values are given in Figure 1(b). Those simulations remind us that the condition R0>μ+γμ of Theorem 4 may not be necessary for the global stability. It is a pity that we cannot prove the global stability without the condition R0>μ+γμ.
body_text.section: 5.1 Simulations of model (1) ::: 5 Numerical simulations

body_text.text: For the case δ>0, we choose δ=0.001, μ=0.01, γ=0.006, and Λ=20. Then we have max{δμ−δ−γ,μ+δ+γμ}=1.7, (1+2μ+δ+γ)μμ+δ=107.86, μ2>(μ+δ)(μ+δ+γ)22+μ+δ+γ, and μ>δ+γ. Theorem 5 implies that the endemic equilibrium E∗ is globally asymptotically stable when 1.7<R0<107.86. Figure 1(c) shows the global stability of the endemic equilibrium of model (1) for β=0.03 and R0=1.765>1. The straightforward calculation shows that R0∈(1,1.7) for those parameter values and β∈(0.017,0.0289). Although R0∈(1,1.7) does not satisfy the conditions of Theorem 5, the numerical simulation shows that the endemic equilibrium of model (1) may still be globally asymptotically stable for R0∈(1,1.7). Figure 1(d) gives the number of the infected people for β=0.02 and R0=1.176, where the condition of Theorem 5 does not hold, but the number of infected people approaches its equilibrium.
body_text.section: 5.1 Simulations of model (1) ::: 5 Numerical simulations

body_text.text: From the epidemiological interpretation, we assume that the inequalities 0<μ+δ+γ<1 and β+μ<1 hold. If those two inequalities hold, then all solutions of model (1) with positive initial values are non-negative, and the numerical simulations show that model (1) does not exhibit complex dynamics. If those two inequalities do not hold, then model (1) may exhibit much more complicated dynamical behaviors. The numerical simulation demonstrates that there exists a sequence of period-doubling bifurcation to chaos. Let us take μ=0.01, γ=0.001, δ=0.001, and Λ=20 to investigate the period doubling process of model (1). For small R0 (a linear function of β), the endemic equilibrium is unique and globally asymptotically stable (see Figure 2(a)). When R0 passes through 186.8, the endemic equilibrium losses its stability, and a stable periodic solution of period 2 appears (see Figure 2(b)). When R0 passes through 226.8, the periodic solution of period 2 losses its stability, and a stable periodic solution of period four appears (see Figure 2(c)). As R0 increases further, the periodic solution of period 4 becomes unstable, and a periodic solution of period 8 appears. The numerical simulation shows that the period-doubling bifurcation may continue and go to chaos (see Figure 2(d)).
body_text.section: 5.1 Simulations of model (1) ::: 5 Numerical simulations

body_text.text: The simulation in this subsection is an application of the SIR model to the mumps infection in China. The model parameters are estimated according to the demographic and epidemiological data in China from 2005 to 2010. We have compared the model simulation result of the number of annual mumps cases to the reported number of notifiable diseases.
body_text.section: 5.2 Application of model (1) ::: 5 Numerical simulations

body_text.text: Mumps, caused by the mumps virus, is an acute respirator infectious disease and it is spread from person to person by coughing or sneezing. Mumps usually starts with a fever and headache for a day or two. It then presents with swelling and soreness of the parotid salivary gland. The main symptom of mumps is the swollen, painful salivary glands on one or both sides of the face. The entire course of mumps infection is 10 to 14 days. The infected people will obtain permanent immunity after they get recovered from infection. The SIR model is suitable to describe the infection of mumps due to its permanent immunity. The host population is chosen to be individuals who are younger than 20 since mumps is common in children and adolescents, but rare among adults. The values of model parameters are estimated from the demographic and epidemiological data in China from 2005 to 2010.
body_text.section: 5.2 Application of model (1) ::: 5 Numerical simulations

body_text.text: In the application of the SIR model, the simulation time unit is taken as one day. All the parameter values will be estimated on the basis of that time unit. From the statistical yearbook of China, we know that the number of the host population (less than twenty years old) in 2005 is 359 million [18]. The annual birth rate in China from 2005 to 2010 is approximately 12/1,000, and the recruitment rate is taken as Λ=44,054 [18–21]. The annual death rate of the population is 7.06/1,000 [22, 23], hence, the daily death rate is 19.34/1,000,000. Since the age of the host population is less than twenty, an individual should be removed when his/her age is over twenty. The daily removed rate is taken to be 1/7,300, and the value of parameter μ is estimated to be μ=0.00001934+0.000137=0.00015634. From the fact that the entire course of mumps infection is 10 to 14 days, we take γ=1/12=0.0833 [24]. From the report on notifiable infectious diseases in China, we take δ=0.0000003.
body_text.section: 5.2 Application of model (1) ::: 5 Numerical simulations

body_text.text: The initial time is taken to be January first of 2005. From the data of China population and notifiable diseases in 2005 [25], the initial values are taken to be S(1)=353,117,392, I(1)=8,508, and R(1)=6,000,000, respectively. By using the method of parameter estimation in [26], we have β=0.08518. After the parameters and initial values are set, we apply the SIS model to simulate the mumps infection in China from 2005 to 2015. The simulation results are shown in Figure 3. The top left plot is the number of the susceptibles, S(t), which shows a slow downward tendency. From the demographic data in China, we know that the number of the population younger than twenty is 359 million in 2005, 320 million in 2009, and 302 million in 2010 [18, 20, 23]. The change of the host population in our simulation is consistent with the observed data. The top right is the number of the infective, I(t), which shows the slow upward tendency. The bottom left is the number of the recovered R(t). The curve in the bottom right plot is the number of new mumps infection cases from 2005 to 2015 by a model simulation. The piecewise curve with stars is the number of annually reported mumps cases out of notifiable infectious diseases from 2005 to 2011 [25]. The comparison between the model simulation and the notifiable disease report demonstrates that our model can give a good prediction for infection diseases.
body_text.section: 5.2 Application of model (1) ::: 5 Numerical simulations

body_text.text: SIR models are suitable to describe the transmission of infectious diseases with life long immunity. A lot of continuous SIR models with various transmission rates have been formulated and studied. The global stability of the endemic equilibrium of the continuous SIR model has been investigated extensively and many sufficient conditions have been obtained. Nevertheless, the discrete SIR model and its dynamics are quite few. In this paper, we have formulated a discrete SIR epidemic model and studied its asymptotical behaviors. Especially, we have got some sufficient conditions for the global stability of the endemic equilibrium. We have also applied the SIR model to the mumps infection in China. The model simulation results match the reported data of the notifiable diseases well.
body_text.section: 6 Conclusion

body_text.text: Although the SIR model considered in this paper is quite simple, it exhibits very complicated dynamical behavior. The complicated dynamics of the simple SIR model reminds us that we cannot expect to have the global stability of the endemic equilibrium when R0>1. Other conditions should be given for the global stability. In this paper we have obtained sufficient conditions for the global stability of the endemic equilibrium. Although those conditions given in our paper are not satisfactory, our result is a good exploration of the challengeable problem. We expect to prove the global stability of the endemic equilibrium when R0 is not large. The comparison principle used in this paper and the Lyapunov function may help us to have better results.
body_text.section: 6 Conclusion

FIGREF0.text: Figure 1: The global stability of the endemic equilibrium of model (1).

FIGREF1.text: Figure 2: The bifurcation diagram of the endemic equilibria and periodic solutions of model (1).

FIGREF2.text:
Figure 3: 
The simulation of mumps infection in China from 2005 to 2015.
